pred:
Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles and the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, has achieved the record of becoming the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo. Sears completed a 702-mile trek through harsh Antarctic conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures as low as -50°C, in 38 days. His journey ended on Christmas Day, more than 12 days ahead of schedule.

The Guinness Book of Records is yet to confirm whether Sears' feat will be recognized as a record. The trek was particularly challenging due to the dangerous crevasses in the initial part of the journey from Hercules Inlet, where sea ice meets land in Antarctica. Skiing alone, Sears had to navigate these crevasses without the safety of being roped to a teammate.

Sears faced a significant challenge in the final stages of his journey, describing in a blog post that he hit a wall with just 38km (24 miles) to go on Christmas Eve. He overcame this hurdle with some food, music, and rest. On Christmas Day, he reached the South Pole in clear skies, expressing his joy in a post.

Sears expects it will take a few weeks for the experience to fully sink in. He is looking forward to a shower and food after spending nearly six weeks alone in a tent. Sears has raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which was devastated by the 2015 earthquake.

Andy Murray's mother, Judy Murray, congratulated Sears on his achievement, tweeting her congratulations. Sears' journey has been widely reported, with media outlets highlighting his record-breaking achievement and charitable efforts.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

pred:
Michael David Elliot, a 40-year-old man convicted of four murders in 1993 and serving five life sentences, escaped from the Ionia Correctional Facility in Michigan on Sunday. After a 24-hour run from the law, Elliot was captured in Kankakee Township, LaPorte County, Indiana on Monday evening. He was arraigned on auto theft charges in Indiana.

The LaPorte County Sheriff’s Department had been looking for a stolen black 2002 Chevrolet Monte Carlo, which was taken from the area of Boyd Avenue and E. Lincolnway in LaPorte. Deputy Slawek Czupryna spotted the stolen vehicle and attempted a traffic stop, but the driver fled, leading deputies on a short chase. Stop Sticks were deployed, and Elliot lost control of the vehicle, crashing into a snowbank in Kankakee Township. He was pulled from the car, handcuffed, and taken to the LaPorte County Jail.

Elliot's escape from the Ionia Correctional Facility was noticed during a routine prisoner check at 9 p.m. on Sunday. He left through the sally port, a secured garage where prisoners are brought into the facility, and got through a hole in the fencing system. Elliot then carjacked a woman, drove to the Elkhart, Ind. area, and abandoned the vehicle in Shipshewana, Ind.

The woman he carjacked escaped at a gas station in Elkhart and Elliot fled in her Jeep Liberty. That SUV was found in Shipshewana on Monday afternoon. Police went door-to-door looking for any signs of Elliot in Shipshewana, but their hunt for him in the area has been suspended with no new leads.

Elliot was serving five life sentences in the Ionia Correctional Facility after being convicted of four 1993 murders. In the early morning of Aug. 8, 1993, Elliot broke into a home in Bentley Township, north of Midland, killed four people, and set the house on fire. Charles Treece, who was also convicted of four counts of first-degree murder, armed robbery, and setting a house on fire, is serving life in prison at the Alger Correctional
answers: A convicted killer who escaped from a Michigan prison yesterday and carjacked a woman has been arrested after a car chase in rural LaPorte Country, Indiana, WNDU reports. Michael David Elliot, 40, allegedly stole a woman's red jeep and abandoned it in the small town of Shipshewana, Indiana, this afternoon. A woman spotted the car and called police, who said the vehicle had been seen in the area as early as 5:30am. Knowing Elliot "can go a lot of places in seven hours," police went door-to-door and had schools locked down before releasing students under a heavy police presence. Then a call about a stolen vehicle came in to the LaPorte County Sheriff's Office, and a deputy saw the vehicle and attempted a traffic stop, WOOD-TV reports. But the driver kept going and led authorities on a 5-minute chase. Stop sticks disabled his tires in Kankakee Township; Elliot jumped out and tried to run but was arrested and booked. He was serving five life sentences for the murders of four people when he broke out of the Ionia Correctional Facility yesterday by slipping through a gap in the fencing system.

pred:
On Friday night, a high-speed chase involving a stolen tractor towing an attachment occurred in central Denver. The chase, which began near City Park, ended in Lower Downtown after the tractor was pursued by a number of Denver Police Department vehicles. The tractor was initially stolen from a Denver Water facility in the Lincoln Park neighborhood.

During the pursuit, the tractor swerved through busy city streets and sidewalks, striking several cars and buildings. The chase ended when a police cruiser rammed the tractor, causing it to stop. Two police officers were injured in the incident and were taken to the hospital. By Saturday morning, both officers had been treated and released.

One witness reported that the tractor driver was apprehended and placed in an ambulance, while another witness praised the actions of the officer who rammed their vehicle into the tractor, ending the pursuit. No gunshots were fired during the incident.

The suspect's identity has not been released as the investigation is ongoing. The Denver Police Department held a press conference to provide updates on the incident, and the hospital is treating the injured officers. The Denver Water department is also involved in the investigation.

This incident caused significant disruption in the downtown area, and videos of the chase have been shared on social media. The Denver Police Department has not yet released details regarding the circumstances of the chase, and further updates are expected as the investigation continues.
answers: Imagine looking outside and seeing over a dozen cop cars chasing ... a tractor. That was the scene in Denver last night when a stolen tractor towing an attachment smashed into cars and buildings as it plowed through downtown, the Huffington Post reports. Addie Hooper, 20, was visiting from Texas with family when she looked out a restaurant window onto Market Street and saw a police SUV crash into the tractor: "We were just like, 'Woah, that's crazy!" Hooper tells the Denver Post. Police vehicles rushed the scene and officers jumped out with guns drawn. "We thought they were going to shoot him," she adds. Instead, officers Tased the driver and made sure he was carted off by ambulance. Two officers sustained non-life-threatening injuries, and no reports have emerged of injured pedestrians. "It could've definitely been a lot worse," a witness tells KDVR. No more details have emerged, but police say the slow-speed chase began around City Park and concluded downtown, where officers rammed the tractor to protect pedestrians. Among Twitter videos, this one seems to capture it best. (Read about the easiest suspect chase ever.)

pred:
In the past few days, tensions between Israelis and Palestinians have escalated significantly, following a series of violent incidents. On Wednesday, a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Hussein Abu Khdeir, aged 16, was abducted and killed near his home in Jerusalem. His body was found charred in a forest on the outskirts of the city, and his family believes he was targeted in revenge for the deaths of three Jewish Israeli teens who were buried hours earlier. The crime has been strongly condemned by the Obama Administration and European officials, and has raised fears of further escalation in the conflict.

The abduction followed a night of violence by Jewish extremists in Jerusalem, who marched through the city chanting "Death to the Arabs" and assaulting Arab Israelis. The funeral of Mohammed Abu Khdeir was delayed so that a post-mortem examination could be completed, and his body was found to be burnt beyond recognition. His father, Hussein Saed Abu Khdeir, accused Jewish settlers of killing his son and demanded justice.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has urged both sides "not to take the law into your own hands" and promised to "uncover quickly who is behind this despicable murder and what motivated it." The Israeli government has also begun reinforcing forces on its border with Gaza in response to mortar and rocket fire from Palestinian militants.

Palestinian leaders have accused Israel of bearing full responsibility for the incident and have threatened to drag Israel before U.N. courts. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas has called for the "strongest punishment against the murderers." There are fears that the funeral, when it does take place, will be followed by more clashes like those which erupted outside the teenager's home on Wednesday.

The family of one of the three murdered Israeli teenagers has also issued a statement condemning the latest killing. "If the Arab youth was murdered because of nationalistic motives, then this is a horrible and horrendous act," the statement said. Israeli police are still investigating the motives for the killing.

The murder of Mohammed Abu Khdeir has sparked widespread outrage and condemnation, and has further strained relations between Israelis and Palestinians. Both sides are urging caution and calling for an end to the violence.
answers: Mohammed Abu Khudair was heading to morning prayers at 4am yesterday when neighbors saw him forced into a van in east Jerusalem, his father says. They called his cell phone but "my son wasn't answering," his mother adds, per the BBC. An hour later, the Palestinian teen was found dead in an apparent revenge killing, so burned beyond recognition that DNA samples were needed to confirm his identify, father Hussein Abu Khudair tells NBC News, adding, per Time, "The settlers killed my son, they kidnapped him and killed him." More developments: The teen's funeral, originally set for today, has been delayed as authorities perform an autopsy, his father says. Khudair adds he doesn't have faith in the Israeli police "because we're Arab" and says young Jews pulled a 9-year-old boy away from his mother after Mohammed's death. Though he was saved, "he was scratched," Khudair says. "They grabbed him by his neck." Another relative of Mohammed adds "the hatred has increased" instantly in the family's neighborhood. "I've never seen such racism, even in the first and second intifada," he tells the New York Times. "We are entering a very dark time." Meanwhile, police are investigating what could be a third kidnapping after a girl called police from northern Israel. "She said that she was abducted and then the line went dead," an Israeli spokesman tells the Times. "We're searching the area. Helicopters are trying to track. We'll see what's going on there." In response to mortar and rocket attacks from Gaza, "the Israeli Air Force attacked 15 terror sites in Gaza early Thursday," an Israel Defense Forces official notes. "The targets included weapons manufacturing sites as well as training facilities." Some 10 Palestinians were reportedly injured.

pred:
In Other Words, a feminist bookstore in Portland, Oregon, has severed ties with the popular TV show Portlandia, which for six seasons used the bookstore as a filming location for its fictional bookstore Women and Women First. The decision was made in response to a series of issues, including the show's portrayal of transgender individuals, lack of diversity, and the negative impact on the neighborhood due to filming.

The bookstore's management claims that the show's trans-antagonistic and trans-misogynist segments are offensive and harmful, particularly in light of the ongoing violence against transgender individuals, especially Black trans women. They also criticize the show for its lack of diversity, as Portland, while predominantly white, is not as white as Portlandia portrays it to be.

Moreover, the bookstore argues that being on Portlandia does not bring in significant financial gains. While they receive a small fee for each episode filmed, the profits lost due to having to close for filming and the business lost by neighboring establishments outweigh this income. The additional exposure from the show does not translate into increased sales or support.

The bookstore also accuses Portlandia of contributing to gentrification in Portland. They argue that the show's popularity is being used by realtors to make displacing communities seem trendy and acceptable, which is harmful to the city's social fabric.

It's important to note that the current board, staff, and volunteers were not involved in the initial decision to allow Portlandia to film at In Other Words. The bookstore is now asking for donations to continue serving as a hub for Portland's social justice community and welcomes volunteers. They have also displayed a "Fuck Portlandia" sign in their window to express their stance.
answers: Portland's In Other Words bookstore is well known to Portlandia fans as the fictional Women and Women First bookstore featured in sketches on the show—but it's safe to say ties have been severed between the bookstore and the show, considering a sign that appears on the bookstore's door reading, "Fuck Portlandia! Transmisogyny – Racism – Gentrification – Queer Antagonism – Devaluation of Feminist Discourse." The Willamette Week tried on Tuesday to get an explanation from the bookstore, and a representative at first offered an interview, but also asked (repeatedly) for the Week to post a link to an online fundraiser the bookstore is running. After the Week declined to guarantee a link would be posted (though one did, in fact, end up getting posted in the ensuing article), the bookstore took back its offer of an interview in no uncertain terms. "After some consideration and research we've decided to officially tell the Willamette Weekly to go fuck themselves," read a message from the rep. "Your paper has absolutely zero journalistic professionalism and you are scummy rape apologists. Thanks for the opportunity tho! Have a great night." Then, Wednesday, a blog post went up on the bookstore's website explaining the "Fuck Portlandia" sign. It was placed on the window, and the store's relationship with the show was formally discontinued, as "a direct response to a particular egregious filming of the show in our space which saw our store left a mess, our staff mistreated, our neighbors forced to close and lose business for a day without warning, and our repeated attempts to obtain accountability or resolution dismissed," the blog post reads. "It was also a direct response to a show which is in every way diametrically opposed to our politics and the vision of society we’re organizing to realize. A show which has had a net negative effect on our neighborhood and the city of Portland as a whole." There's a lot more where that came from, here.

In a series of investigations conducted by the California State Auditor's Office, several instances of improper governmental activities by state employees and agencies have been uncovered. These activities include misuse of state time, economically wasteful activities, and misuse of government property.

1. Four state employees across various agencies were found to have misused state time, costing the State approximately $160,000. Two employees took extended breaks or left the premises over a five-year period, one employee regularly left early from work over two years, and one employee slept at her desk for extended periods during work hours.

2. A nursing director at a state prison removed a licensed vocational nurse, who was her personal friend, from her assigned nursing position to perform duties typically performed by an office technician. This decision resulted in unnecessary salary payments and overtime costs totaling nearly $30,000.

3. An official built an unauthorized structure on state property with the help of on-duty staff under his command.

4. Two facilities operations employees at California State University, Fresno engaged in time and attendance abuse by taking extended breaks or leaving campus without accounting for their time, costing the State over $111,000 in salary paid for work not performed.

5. A key data operator at the Department of Motor Vehicles failed to perform her essential duties over a period of nearly four years because she slept at her desk for extended periods of time during work hours, misusing more than 2,200 hours of work time and costing the State over $40,000.

6. A high-ranking Cal Fire chief had two state employees build an addition to a state-owned house he rented during their work hours without permission. The assistant chief was punished with a 30-day suspension, and Cal Fire has demolished the structure.

The California Whistleblower Protection Act empowers the California State Auditor's Office to investigate and report on improper governmental activities by agencies and employees of the State. From July 1, 2017, through June 30, 2018, the State Auditor conducted investigative work on 1,481 cases, substantiating improper governmental activities in seven examples. During the past year, the State Auditor also issued non
answers: An employee responsible for logging changes in address and vehicle ownership at the California DMV slept at least three hours a day at her desk for nearly four years—and still has a job. The woman's 2,200 hours spent napping between February 2014 and December 2017 meant she completed less than half of her expected amount of work and cost the state more than $40,000, according to a worker misconduct report released Tuesday by the state's auditor. Per USA Today, the woman's doctor told the DMV that she was unable to perform her work duties, though a later doctor's note said the opposite. The employee continues to work for the state, per the Sacramento Bee.

pred:
In Cairo, Egypt, political tensions escalated on December 5 and 6 as supporters and opponents of President Mohamed Mursi clashed outside the presidential palace. The conflict stemmed from Mursi's drive to push through a new constitution, which has been met with opposition from various groups. The Muslim Brotherhood, an Islamist political organization, called for a protest outside the palace in response to what they described as "oppressive abuses" by opposition parties.

On December 5, stones and petrol bombs were exchanged between opposition protesters and supporters of Mursi. Two Islamists were reportedly hit by gunfire during the clashes, and 23 people were wounded in total. Vice President Mahmoud Mekky proposed a solution to end the crisis, suggesting that amendments to disputed articles in the draft constitution could be agreed upon with the opposition, with a written agreement then submitted to the next parliament, to be elected after a referendum on the constitution on December 15.

The following day, on December 6, fighting continued into the early morning, with fires burning in the streets near the palace. A total of 211 people were reported wounded, some with gunshot wounds. Protesters chanted slogans such as "No to dictatorship" and "Defending Mursi is defending Islam."

The United States and British Foreign Secretary William Hague called for dialogue and restraint on all sides, expressing concern about the stability of Egypt, a state that has a peace deal with Israel and receives significant financial aid from the U.S. and other countries. Mursi has shown no signs of backing down, confident that the Islamists, who have dominated elections since the ousting of former President Hosni Mubarak, can win the referendum and parliamentary election to follow.

The opposition coalition has accused Mursi of creating a new autocracy and blamed him for the violence. They are ready for dialogue if the constitutional decree is scrapped and the referendum on the constitution is postponed. However, the opposition has yet to generate a mass movement or a grassroots base to challenge the Brotherhood.

The clashes and political instability have caused frustration among residents, with some setting up makeshift roadblocks to check passers-by, reminiscent of the popular uprising that top
answers: Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi returned to the presidential palace today after fleeing yesterday when it was thronged by protesters, Reuters reports. Though 200 demonstrators camped out overnight, traffic was back to normal today and riot police had left the area. In yesterday's clashes, 35 protesters and 40 police officers were hurt. And things are looking to heat up again soon: The Muslim Brotherhood has called for a protest at the palace today against the "oppressive abuses" of the opposition, and the opposition in response called for leftist demonstrators to head back to the palace, leading to fears of violent clashes. Opposition protesters want Morsi to retract his expanded powers and stop a Dec. 15 vote on the new constitution hastily drafted by Islamists. Though they called yesterday's protest a "last warning" to the president, Reuters notes that they have little real chance of stopping the vote, which Morsi is confident will approve the constitution.

pred:
The Jamaican Bobsled Team is set to compete in the two-man bobsled event at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, on February 16, 2014. The team, piloted by Winston Watts, has made a unique comeback to the Winter Olympics after a 12-year absence. To support and cheer for the team, a catchy reggae song titled "The Bobsled Song" has been released. The song, written by Sidney Mills and Jon Notar, and produced by Groove Guild, is designed to sync perfectly with the rhythms of the bobsled track.

The song's lyrics and chorus follow the course of the 1,500-meter track with its 17 turns and vertical drop of 125.5 meters. The lyrics encourage the team to keep their head down and focus on the finish line, with the final part of the song proclaiming, "Last turn, keep your head down/I see the finish line/Jamaica rock the whole town."

The Jamaican Tourist Board is promoting the song and has released an eight-bit animated music video for it. The video tracks the team's progress on a map of the Sochi bobsled course. The team qualified for the competition without racing in any World Cup events but accumulating enough points in lower-tier races in North America.

Despite being considered a long shot to win a medal, the Jamaican team's journey to the Winter Olympics is reminiscent of their first appearance in the 1988 Calgary Games, which was depicted in the film "Cool Runnings." Fans can download the song at BobsledSong.com and start playing it just as the Jamaican Bobsled Team begins their race on February 16 at 11:15 AM EST.
answers: Jamaica's incredible bobsledding run to the Winter Olympics now has a theme song to go with it—named, appropriately, "The Bobsled Song," the AP reports. The upbeat tune by Sidney Mills and Jon Notard plays perfectly in sync with the team's 4,921-foot run in Sochi and wraps up with "Last turn, keep your head down/I see the finish line/Jamaica rock the whole town," reports Mashable. (See the 8-bit video here.) Considered a long shot to win a medal, the two-man team of Marvin Dixon and Winston Watts are aiming to recapture the thrill of the 1988 film Cool Runnings and ride the crowd-funding high that paid for country's first bobsledding Olympic appearance since 2002.

pred:
Two former Nazi SS guards, aged 93 and 92, have been indicted by German prosecutors for being accessories to murder while they worked at the Stutthof concentration camp during World War II. The men, from Borken and Wuppertal, served at the camp from 1942 to 1945. The charges were filed under new legal reasoning that allows the prosecution of former Nazis who helped camps operate, even without evidence of a specific crime.

Holocaust survivor Judith Meisel, 88, from St. Louis Park, Minnesota, has played a crucial role in the case. She identified one of the ex-guards, Johann Rehbogen, as a teenage SS officer who taunted her and other female prisoners at the camp. Meisel has provided essential details about life in the camp to challenge the defendants' denials of knowledge about the killings.

The charges against Rehbogen and Harry Paul Fritz Schulz represent a new chapter for Holocaust survivors like Meisel, who are seeking answers and justice for their lost family members. If found guilty, the defendants could face prison sentences. The trial is expected to commence next summer if the defendants are deemed healthy enough.

Meisel, who has been reliving her experiences at the camp, welcomes the opportunity to testify and share her story for the important lessons it teaches about tolerance and racism. The charges have brought back vivid memories for Meisel, including witnessing camp inmates killed by injections administered by Stutthof doctors.

German authorities have named witnesses from Ohio, New Jersey, New York, and Florida in the case. The indictments are part of a broader effort by German authorities to pursue cases against Nazis who helped operate concentration camps during the war. The charges have come as a surprise to Meisel's family, who are supportive of the prosecution.

Meisel's son, Michael Cohen, a Minneapolis attorney, said his mother has been affected by the wave of emotions since learning of the indictments. Despite the toll it has taken on her, Meisel remains committed to sharing her story to teach important lessons about tolerance and racism. She cannot forget the message from some of her fellow prisoners: "Don't let us die without you mentioning what happened to us."
answers: Judith Meisel says that when she was a teenager in the Stutthof concentration camp in western Poland, other prisoners told her: "Don't let us die without you mentioning what happened to us." The 88-year-old Minnesota resident has not forgotten: Her testimony helped German authorities indict two former guards from the camp where 65,000 people, including Meisel's mother, died, the Minneapolis Star Tribune reports. She identified one former guard, 94-year-old Johann Rehbogen, as the young SS officer who would taunt female prisoners as they undressed. Prosecutors say the men can't be tied to specific murders, but their work as guards made the killings possible. Meisel—who escaped along with her sister when inmates were sent on a "death march" away from the camp in 1945—says she is willing to relive her horrific experiences to help prosecutors. "This process of seeking answers and finding justice for my mother gives new meaning to my life," she says. The two former guards have been charged as accessories to murder, the AP reports. They deny any knowledge of killings at the camp, where thousands were starved to death or froze. Prosecutors say prisoners were also gassed to death, shot, and killed with lethal injections. Authorities say Meisel and several other Stutthof survivors in the US could be called as witnesses if the former guards are deemed healthy enough to stand trial. (A pendant found at the Sobibor camp helped reunite a family.)

pred:
In the first passage, a person reflects on the power held by individuals, particularly in the context of political leaders, and how they can use that power to enact positive change and serve as symbols of democracy. They express the ability to refuse to acknowledge a President and call out abuses of power, and to vote for a President based on their character.

In the second passage, new accusations of inappropriate behavior have been made against former President George H.W. Bush. Actress Jordana Grolnick has come forward, stating that Bush touched her inappropriately during a photo opportunity in 2016. She claims that Bush grabbed her and made a lewd joke while posing for a picture. This incident follows an earlier accusation by actress Heather Lind, who alleged that Bush sexually assaulted her during a photo opportunity in 2013. Bush has since issued apologies for both incidents, stating that his actions were intended as a joke and that he did not mean to offend.

The accusations against Bush come in the wake of the Weinstein scandal and the fallout of many film and TV executives due to sexual harassment allegations. Lind's colleagues, including co-star Kevin McNally and the author of the book on which the show Turn is based, have come forward to support her allegations. The official Turn account also tweeted in support of Lind, stating that sexual assault is always about abusing power over victims and that the real issue should not be politicized.

The summary highlights the ongoing issue of sexual harassment and the importance of holding powerful individuals accountable for their actions. It also underscores the power of individuals to use their voices to speak out against inappropriate behavior and to support those who have been victimized. The person in the first passage emphasizes the importance of using power to enact positive change and to serve as a symbol of democracy, and the events in the second passage demonstrate the potential consequences of abusing that power.
answers: Actress Heather Lind accused former President George HW Bush of sexual assault in a now-deleted Instagram post Tuesday, saying the former president "touched her from behind" during a photo-op in 2014. The Turn: Washington's Spies star said the inappropriate behavior occurred during a special screening before the AMC historical drama's debut, Deadline reports. "He touched me from behind from his wheelchair with his wife Barbara Bush by his side," Lind wrote. "He told me a dirty joke. And then, all the while being photographed, touched me again. Barbara rolled her eyes as if to say 'not again.'" Lind said a security guard told her she "shouldn't have stood next to him for the photo." Lind said that judging from comments from people around her, Bush had behaved the same way with "countless other women." "My fellow castmates and producers helped me that day and continue to support me," she wrote. Lind said she decided to come forward with her story after seeing a recent photo of the 93-year-old Bush with former President Obama. Bush issued an apology through a spokesman. "President Bush would never—under any circumstance—intentionally cause anyone distress, and he most sincerely apologizes if his attempt at humor offended Ms. Lind," the spokesman said in a statement to the New York Daily News.

pred:
In Tunisia, a significant number of Libyan refugees, estimated to be around 30,000, have fled the ongoing conflict in Libya and found shelter with local residents, particularly in the town of Tataouine. This act of generosity has been praised by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Firas Kayal, who finds it remarkable given the challenges Tunisia faces following its own revolution and previous waves of Libyan refugees. The Tunisian government has also kept the country's borders open, with an estimated 276,000 people, most of them foreign workers, having fled Libya for Tunisia.

Meanwhile, the conflict in Libya has spilled over into Tunisia, with Libyan government troops battling rebels on Tunisian territory for control of the Dehiba-Wazin frontier crossing. This incursion, while brief and limited, has caused outrage in Tunisia, with the Tunisian authorities demanding immediate action to stop these violations. The fighting in Libya has also intensified in the port city of Misrata, with rebels accusing Gaddafi's forces of firing bigger rockets, causing greater destruction. The rebels have called on NATO to intervene, stating that the current military deadlock can only be solved by NATO air strikes.

NATO has been conducting air strikes on Libya since last month under a U.N. Security Council resolution calling for the protection of civilians. However, the conflict has exposed growing international rifts, with critics of NATO bombing calling it another case of the West trying to overthrow a government by stretching the terms of a U.N. resolution. The conflict in Libya continues, with reports of clashes and shelling in various parts of the country.
answers: Tunisia was not pleased today when a battle between Libya’s warring factions spilled across the border today, after Moammar Gadhafi’s forces attacked a rebel-held frontier crossing. The incursion was brief and limited, and Gadhafi’s forces even apologized locally, Reuters reports. But Tunisia’s foreign ministry still issued a statement expressing “extreme indignation” and demanding “measures to put an immediate stop to these violations.” But Tunisia has proven remarkably welcoming to Libyans who aren’t fighting. Some 30,000 refugees have fled there, and the vast majority of them have been welcomed into the homes of Tunisians, the New York Times reports. Only about 2,500 have had to settle in the relatively small refugee camp at the border. “It’s the first time I’ve seen such an impressive response,” says a spokesman for the UN’s High Commissioner for Refugees.

In the political sphere, Republican presidential candidate Rick Perry has found himself in an unusual spotlight due to an animated and expressive speech he delivered in Manchester, New Hampshire. The event, which took place on Friday, was captured on video and later edited into a montage that highlights the more unconventional moments of his roughly 25-minute speech.

The video, posted on YouTube by an account named CharlieJohnson1986, has sparked speculation about Perry's state during the speech. Mother Jones published a video showing Perry accepting a jug of maple syrup at the event, suggesting that he may have been "really good, or good and drunk." However, it's important to note that the videos do not provide definitive evidence of intoxication.

The speech was noted for its unusual nature by those who attended, including Manchester Mayor Ted Gatsas, who described it as "different." Initially, Perry's spokesman declined to comment on the matter, but later offered a statement, saying, "The Governor is passionate about the issues he talks about."

It's unclear what specific elements of the speech led to the unusual reactions, as the videos do not provide a full account of his remarks. The original video footage was not reviewed until Saturday afternoon, and the YouTube account owner did not respond to a message seeking further information.

This incident has added another layer of intrigue to Perry's presidential campaign, with the media and public speculating about the reasons behind his animated speech. The campaign has not provided any further explanation, but has emphasized that Perry is passionate about the issues he discusses.
answers: Was Rick Perry pie-eyed during a speech to a conservative group in New Hampshire on Friday? In a video that has since gone viral, the candidate adopted an exuberant, jokey style and pulled a lot of funny faces, leading some commentators to believe that the Texas governor was distinctly refreshed. "It was different," the mayor of Manchester told the Huffington Post after the speech. The speech shows that Perry is "passionate about the issues he talks about," a campaign spokeswoman says. "We're not saying that he's definitely drunk, we're just saying, watch the whole thing," muses Max Read at Gawker.

pred:
The news articles highlight the life and philanthropic work of Julius Rosenwald, a Jewish American businessman and the son of German immigrants. Rosenwald, known as "JR," started his career as a men's clothing salesperson and later partnered with Richard Sears, co-founder of Sears, Roebuck and Co., transforming it into the largest mail-order firm in the world. He was also a significant philanthropist, particularly in African-American education and culture.

Rosenwald's philanthropy had a profound impact on African-American communities in the early 1900s. He provided seed money to build YMCAs for blacks in cities around the country, developed a huge apartment complex in Chicago to improve living conditions for migrants from the Jim Crow South, and funded the building of more than 5,300 schools in the rural South, many of which were named after him. These schools played a crucial role in the education of thousands of African-American children, including civil rights activist John Lewis and poet Maya Angelou.

A new documentary, "Rosenwald," tells the story of his little-known contributions to African-American culture and education. The film features interviews with prominent African-Americans who attended Rosenwald schools, such as John Lewis and Maya Angelou, and explores Rosenwald's influence on Booker T. Washington and his commitment to racial equality. The documentary also highlights the parallels Rosenwald drew between the pogroms against European Jews and violent attacks on blacks in America, and his support for Jewish causes.

The documentary, directed by Aviva Kempner, is part of a trilogy documenting the lives of "under-known Jewish heroes." It is set to be released in theaters in mid-August. The film is seen as a celebration of the affinity between African-Americans and Jews and speaks to the powerful Jewish tradition of tikkun olam, or repairing the world.

The stories of Julius Rosenwald and his philanthropic work serve as an inspiring example of hard work, success, and giving back to the community. His legacy continues to motivate others to engage in philanthropy and social justice efforts.
answers: Julius Rosenwald is well known as the 20th-century American businessman who co-founded what we now call Sears. But a new documentary by Aviva Kempner explores Rosenwald's lesser-known role as a Jewish philanthropist who brought education to thousands of African-American children at a time when most had no schools to attend, reports the Root. "It's a wonderful story of cooperation between this philanthropist who did not have to care about black people, but who did, and who expended his considerable wealth in ensuring that they got their fair shake in America," civil rights leader Julian Bond explains in Rosenwald, out next month. It tells of Rosenwald's rise from the son of a peddler to a clothing manufacturing apprentice to CEO of the largest US retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Co., in 1908, reports the Times of Israel. It was around that time he began to see similarities between the treatment of blacks in America and pogroms against European Jews. When his rabbi became an NAACP leader, Rosenwald sponsored meetings. Soon after, he donated $25,000 to Alabama's Tuskegee University, led by Booker T. Washington, whose writings on racial equality and education had piqued his interest. Washington suggested the money go toward building six schools for black children, but Rosenwald contributed just a third of the funds and pushed the black and white communities to raise the rest. He went on to give $62 million to various causes, including the Rosenwald Fund, which created 5,300 schools in the South, attended by prominent African-Americans like Maya Angelou, George Wolfe, and Eugene Robinson. It "was the single-most important funding agency for African-American culture in the 20th century," poet Rita Dove says. More than 80 years after his death, Rosenwald still inspires. "Not all of us can be Julius Rosenwald," says Kempner, but "we can all do something."

These include introducing girls to female role models, making the responsibilities, roles, and payoffs of leadership clear from a young age, and providing proactive efforts to move women into leadership roles throughout the year. Highlighting the accomplishments of female leaders and providing opportunities for girls to see these women in action at the workplace is also emphasized as a way to inspire girls.

The articles also mention the importance of sponsorship in corporate environments, where sponsors spend their political capital on behalf of their protégés and provide opportunities instead of merely advice. The articles conclude that simply showing girls what an office looks like is no longer enough, and real breakthroughs will come when we bring girls inside the halls of power. answers: Today is the 20th anniversary of Take Our Daughters to Work Day, and Jennifer Allyn at the Christian Science Monitor says it's time to declare mission accomplished and refocus on a bigger goal. Two decades ago, it was enough to get young girls in the workplace and "demystify" the whole concept of women getting a job. Now it's time to introduce girls to the executive suites, to give them role models of women as decision-makers. Girls still tend not to see themselves getting leadership positions as adults, and that's because they don't get to see enough real-life examples. "Simply showing our daughters what an office looks like is no longer enough," writes Allen. "Real breakthroughs will come when we bring girls inside the halls of power. We need to take our daughters into the C-Suite now so they can lead in the future." Click to read her entire column.

The evidence presented includes the use of copper alloy fasteners, which were not common in ships of the 15th or 16th century, and the absence of iron and/or wood fixations that should have been present on the Santa Maria.

The initial discovery was made by US marine archaeologist Barry Clifford in May, who claimed that the geographical, underwater topography, and archaeological evidence strongly suggested that the wreck was Columbus' famous flagship, the Santa Maria. Clifford also pointed out a metallic tube at the site, which he believed to be a cannon.

However, a team of experts led by the former head of the Spanish National Museum on Underwater Archaeology, Xavier Nieto Prieto, concluded that the fasteners found at the site indicated a technique of ship construction that dates the ship to the late 17th or 18th Century rather than the 15th or 16th Century. The team also noted that the site was further away from shore than one should expect, and the metal tube that Clifford had seen during a 2003 expedition was no longer at the site.

Unesco plans to look for the Santa Maria in a number of different locations, both on land and on the seabed. However, many scholars are likely to be critical of Unesco's plan to look for the Santa Maria in coastal marshland, as they argue that Columbus' vessel could not have reached those areas due to shallow and dangerous reefs.

The Santa Maria was the flagship of Christopher Columbus' first voyage to the Americas, which took place in 1492. The ship ran aground on a reef or sandbank off the northern shore of Haiti on the night of 24 to 25 December 1492. The wreck of the Santa Maria was never found, and it could have been buried by sediment over the past centuries or have been slowly worn down by the waves.

The Unesco report may
answers: The United Nations' cultural body is on the trail of Christopher Columbus' flagship—and it says the wreck that an expedition identified as the Santa Maria earlier this year is a different, much younger ship. As predicted by authorities in Haiti, UNESCO experts say there is "indisputable proof" that the wreck found off the country's north coast is from a much later period than 1492, reports the BBC. UNESCO says the wreck is further from shore than accounts of Columbus' first voyage, and bronze or copper fasteners found at the site are evidence of shipbuilding techniques that date the ship to the late 17th or 18th century at the earliest. UNESCO says it believes the wreck may lie "under coastal sediment" in what is now marshland and has called for further investigation of the area. Marine archaeologist Barry Clifford, who first investigated the wreck 11 years ago, says Columbus-era lombard cannons spotted in the area are crucial pieces of evidence that now appear to have been looted from the site, the Independent reports. "The lombards are the smoking guns and, in my view, the most important pieces of evidence in the search for the Santa Maria," he says. (Columbus wrote about the 1492 sinking of the Santa Maria in his journal, but one historian believes that the explorer lied about the ship's fate as part of a spy plot.)

The strange case began in June when police in Casselberry charged Sarah Markham with neglect and took away 2-week-old Caleb. The child has been with his grandparents since he was taken out of his mother's care, and now weighs about 17 pounds. "He's still on a soy formula," says Bo Markham. The criminal neglect charges are still pending, though Sarah Markham's attorney—Mark O'Mara, who defended George Zimmerman—says he expects they will be dismissed now. However, others, such as Representative Adam Schiff, have expressed concern that Trump may be less prepared for his meeting with Putin than the Russian president, and that he may be too eager to find common ground with Putin. The meeting between the two leaders
answers: For the first time since becoming POTUS, Donald Trump has met Russian President Vladimir Putin. The meeting happened on the sidelines of what Reuters calls a "closely watched" G20 summit. They're not kidding, considering the first media coverage coming out of the summit focuses on the handshake between the two, which was of course caught on video. Reuters notes that in addition to the handshake, Trump patted Putin on the arm and later on the back, and both men smiled. Per the Guardian, Trump told Putin, "Mr. Putin, it is an honor to be with you." Putin's reply: "I’m delighted to meet you personally, and I hope our meeting will bring results." The moment took place at an informal meeting of G20 leaders as the summit began in Hamburg, Germany; Trump and Putin are to hold their formal meeting at 3:45pm local time. In a heroic act of bravery, Pedro Viloria, a McDonald's cashier at a Doral, Florida location, sprang into action when an off-duty Miami-Dade police officer, a customer, suddenly lost consciousness while operating her SUV at the drive-thru. Witnessing the woman's struggle, Viloria, who was serving breakfast to the officer and her two children, immediately jumped through the restaurant's drive-thru window to assist.

Surveillance footage captured the moment Viloria pulled the unconscious woman from the moving SUV as it rolled forward. A second McDonald's employee, along with paramedics who were in the restaurant, helped to revive the woman at the scene. She was then taken to the hospital for further treatment.

Viloria, who expressed concern for the children's safety, ensured they called 911 immediately. Firefighters and an off-duty paramedic also arrived to provide assistance. McDonald's has commended Viloria's actions, praising his quick thinking and bravery. The company also acknowledged the efforts of the second employee who assisted with CPR.

As of Wednesday, there has been no update on the woman's condition from Miami-Dade Police Detective Daniel Ferrin. The incident has been widely reported by news outlets, including Fox 5 NY and CBS Miami. Pedro Viloria's actions have been hailed as a testament to his dedication and quick thinking in a critical situation.
answers: McDonald's employee Pedro Viloria doesn't typically jump through the drive-thru window, but a shocking moment during his Tuesday breakfast shift in Doral, Florida, led him to do just that. Now, he's being deemed a hero for his quick actions. Mashable reports that after handing over an order to an off-duty police officer at the pick-up window, Viloria noticed she was struggling to breathe. She then fell unconscious, causing her foot to slide off the brake, per Fox News. The officer’s SUV then began rolling forward with her two children inside, yelling in the back seat. In one swift motion, Viloria leapt through the window to help. (You can see video at CBS Miami. "In that moment, I thought, I'd rather save that woman's life," Viloria tells WPLG. The SUV narrowly missed colliding with another vehicle before coming to a stop at a curb. Another McDonald's employee, who asked to remain unnamed, administered CPR along with a number of first responders who happened to be at or nearby the scene. The condition and identity of the officer has yet to be released after she was transported to the hospital. “I think I speak for our McDonald’s family when I say how proud we are of Pedro," says a statement from McDonald's that also thanked his co-worker. "Their quick thinking and action were everything in that moment.”

In recent news, France has taken a significant step towards legalizing same-sex marriage and adoption rights for same-sex couples. The National Assembly, France's lower house of parliament, approved the controversial bill, known as "marriage for all," by a majority vote of 329 to 229. This legislation, a key election promise of President François Hollande, redefines marriage as a contract between two people rather than a union between a man and a woman.

The bill now moves to the Senate, or upper house, for approval on April 2, where it is expected to pass due to the left-wing majority. If passed, France will join 11 other countries, including Spain, Sweden, South Africa, and the Netherlands, in allowing same-sex marriages. The United States, with nine states and Washington D.C. having legalized same-sex marriage, and the United Kingdom, which recently voted for marriage equality, are also among the nations that support this reform.

The debate over the bill has been contentious, with over 5,000 amendments proposed by the conservative opposition to delay proceedings. The issue has divided the nation, particularly on the question of equal rights for children. While a majority of French citizens support same-sex marriage, less than half agree with equal rights for children.

The Catholic Church and other religious groups, such as Muslims, Jews, and Buddhists, have expressed concern over the draft bill. The Church has accused President Hollande of pushing through the legislation without proper consultation. Protests against the reform have been among the largest in decades, with around 340,000 people participating in Paris on January 14. The anti-gay marriage camp has promised to stage a new rally on March 24.

Despite the opposition, gay rights advocates have welcomed the bill, with the French gay, lesbian, and transgender rights group Inter-LGBT stating that the law, if passed, would be a major advance for equality of rights. The group believes that the law will put an end to outdated discrimination and protect all families without discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity.

In related news, the United Kingdom has taken a step towards legalizing same-sex marriage, with the House of Commons approving the second reading of a bill last week. However, the move has prompted widespread rebellion within Prime Minister David Cameron's
answers: Same-sex marriage is now just one step away from being legal in France. The country's lower house of parliament today voted 329 to 229 to approve a controversial bill that would redefine a marriage as a contract between two people, without reference to gender, allowing gay and lesbian couples to both get married and adopt children, France 24 reports. The bill faced fierce opposition from France's Catholics, and from conservative lawmakers, who introduced more than 5,000 amendments to delay its passage. But now the bill needs only to clear the senate to become law, according to CNN. The vote comes as a similar bill is working its way through the UK parliament.

In a three-year retrospective of the Casey Anthony trial, it is revealed that Casey Anthony, who was acquitted of the murder of her 2-year-old daughter Caylee in 2011, is still effectively imprisoned due to public hatred and threats. Cheney Mason, a Florida defense attorney who represented Anthony, shared this information in an interview promoting his new book, "Justice in America."

According to Mason, Anthony is currently doing some clerical work and legal research, living in an undisclosed location with companions but not dating. He emphasized that the public has not had the opportunity to meet the real Casey Anthony.

Mason's book, set to be released this summer, addresses legal issues, media bias, and courtroom bias in the high-profile case. It will include behind-the-scenes information not previously disclosed to the public. The book is expected to challenge readers to reconsider their judgments about Anthony.

Mason's book is the third about the Casey Anthony trial, following books by co-counsel Jose Baez and prosecutor Jeff Ashton. Mason stated that his book offers unique insights not found in the other books.

The book will be available as an e-book on Monday, with the physical book to be released on August 18. Mason plans to make public appearances to promote the book, but no dates have been announced yet.

In the trial, Anthony was found not guilty of first-degree murder and other serious charges. However, she was convicted on four misdemeanors of providing false information to law enforcement officers. Since her acquittal, Anthony has lived in hiding due to public hostility and threats to her life. She is reportedly wary of strangers and lives a secluded life.

Mason's wife, Shirley, has also developed a relationship with Anthony and offers her support and advice. Despite the public's negative perception of Anthony, Mason expressed hope that people will eventually let go of their hatred and allow Anthony to move on. He also mentioned that Anthony still grieves for her daughter Caylee.

In conclusion, the Casey Anthony trial remains a significant event in American legal history, with ongoing debates about the verdict, media bias, and the impact on Anthony's life. Mason's book aims to shed new light on these issues and provide a
answers: It has been almost exactly three years since Casey Anthony was found not guilty of murdering her 2-year-old daughter Caylee, but she is still essentially a prisoner, one of her lawyers says. Anthony, now 28, lives in an unnamed location in Florida and remains afraid to go out in public because of death threats, Cheney Mason tells CNN. She does clerical work at home for various clients, but "she hasn't been freed from her incarceration yet 'cause she can't go out," the lawyer says. "She can't go to a beauty parlor, she can't go shopping to a department store, she can't go to a restaurant, she can't even go to McDonald's. She can't do anything." The Orlando Sentinel notes that Mason says Anthony doesn't live alone, and isn't romantically involved with anyone. Anthony—who accused her father of sexually abusing her—"does not have any blood family anymore" and the family she has now consists of members of her defense team. Mason says he thinks she "wants to speak out"; Anthony declined CNN's request for an interview, however. "I know she has very strong feelings for what has happened to her. I also know she's very saddened by her loss and she will never forget her daughter Caylee, ever," Mason says. His book, Justice in America: How Prosecutors and the Media Conspire Against the Accused, will be released this summer. Mason—the third attorney associated with the case to write a book—says it will include information never revealed before, and will go beyond the Anthony case to explore broader legal issues.

pred:
In the Rio Olympics 2016, two middle-distance runners, Nikki Hamblin from New Zealand and Abbey D'Agostino from the USA, displayed exceptional sportsmanship during a 5000m heat race. After a collision, both athletes fell to the ground, with D'Agostino helping Hamblin back up. Despite suffering a ruptured anterior cruciate ligament, D'Agostino continued to support Hamblin, enabling her to complete the race. Their act of kindness and sportsmanship was recognized by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) with the Pierre de Coubertin medal, an award given to individuals who embody the Olympic spirit.

The IOC also honored the Norwegian men's handball team for their sportsmanship during a European championship match earlier this year. Despite losing out on their Olympic dream due to an illegal player on the opposing team scoring the final goal, the Norwegian team chose not to file a protest, demonstrating fair play and respect for the rules.

These acts of sportsmanship, embodying the Olympic values of excellence, friendship, respect, fair play, and human spirit, were celebrated at the Olympic Games Rio 2016. The IOC and the International Fair Play Committee (CIFP) presented the Fair Play awards to D'Agostino, Hamblin, and the Norwegian men's handball team, recognizing them as true Olympic champions in sportsmanship.

Nikki Hamblin expressed her gratitude for the recognition, stating that she and D'Agostino did not expect their race to become a significant moment in their lives. She emphasized the importance of sportsmanship on the track, stating that there is a mutual understanding of what it takes to compete.

The Norwegian Handball Federation President, Kaare Geir Lio, commented that the award was energizing and inspiring for the team, reflecting their commitment to fair play and respect as values in Norwegian handball.

The IOC Vice-President, Nawal El Moutawakel, highlighted the inspiring moments of fair play at the Olympics, emphasizing that athletes are role models who can inspire others through their actions.
answers: One of the most touching moments of the Rio Olympics has been rewarded with this year's Fair Play Awards. American runner Abbey D'Agostino and New Zealand's Nikki Hamblin, who helped each other finish the race after falling during a women's 5,000-meter heat, were given the awards Saturday night for what the IOC describes as "two separate acts of selflessness and exemplary sportsmanship." D'Agostino, who was accidentally brought down by Hamblin, helped the New Zealand runner to her feet. Hamblin then stayed with her fellow runner when she realized D'Agostino had injured her leg in the fall. "Winning this award is overwhelming," says Hamblin, per the Sydney Morning Herald. "I am proud [at] what we did and truly believe that you can be both a competitor and kind and responsive at the same time," she says. "Everyone comes here to compete, but there are a lot of people who don't achieve that, and the journey is really important, too." The IOC decided to allow both women to compete in the final, though D'Agostino was too injured to take part, the Guardian reports.
